Data: Gundam Build Fighters is a toy show through and through. It also just happens to be some of the most fun we had with an anime in a long time! ― Gundam is a mecha franchise that's been going strong for decades with amazing entries in all kinds of styles. KLabGames Celebrates April Fool's Day Special In-Game Campaigns   Apr  2nd 2022         Tokyo, Japan – April 1, 2022 –  KLab Inc., a leader in online mobile games, announced that the following titles will feature limited-time special campaigns in celebration of April Fool's Day. The global versions of Captain Tsubasa: Dream Team, Bleach: Brave Souls, and Utano☆Princesama Shining Live will feature in-game campaigns today only, Friday, April 1.  Users can receive amazing rewards based on the different campaigns in each title so don't miss out on this great chance to start playing!  Games Featuring April Fool's Day Campaigns Captain Tsubasa: Dream Team Bleach: Brave Souls Utano☆Princesama Shining Live  Captain Tsubasa: Dream Team  A special one-day event based off of the Captain Tsubasa comic World Youth Edition will be held in-game including an original scenario. The protagonists of the story will be Munemasa Katagiri, Minato Gamo, and Tatsuo Mikami. Users can get the new SSR Players for clearing the event scenario. There will also be a special Get UR Players as a Present! April Fools' 10-Player Transfer so be sure to check it out!  Event Period: From Friday, April 1 at 0:00 to Friday, April 1 at 23:59 JST (UTC+9)  Download here! KLabGames Celebrates April Fool's Day Special In-Game Campaigns   Apr  2nd 2022         Tokyo, Japan – April 1, 2022 –  KLab Inc., a leader in online mobile games, announced that the following titles will feature limited-time special campaigns in celebration of April Fool's Day. The global versions of Captain Tsubasa: Dream Team, Bleach: Brave Souls, and Utano☆Princesama Shining Live will feature in-game campaigns today only, Friday, April 1.  Users can receive amazing rewards based on the different campaigns in each title so don't miss out on this great chance to start playing!  Games Featuring April Fool's Day Campaigns Captain Tsubasa: Dream Team Bleach: Brave Souls Utano☆Princesama Shining Live  Captain Tsubasa: Dream Team  A special one-day event based off of the Captain Tsubasa comic World Youth Edition will be held in-game including an original scenario. The protagonists of the story will be Munemasa Katagiri, Minato Gamo, and Tatsuo Mikami. Users can get the new SSR Players for clearing the event scenario. There will also be a special Get UR Players as a Present! April Fools' 10-Player Transfer so be sure to check it out!  Event Period: From Friday, April 1 at 0:00 to Friday, April 1 at 23:59 JST (UTC+9)  Download here! Check out the tweets posted by Kon with the hashtag "#kingkon"!  Download here! During the limited-time event, chibi versions of the idols will appear on the main screen. Clear lives and collect World of April Fools' Corsages to unlock the special story! KLabGames Celebrates April Fool's Day Special In-Game Campaigns   Apr  2nd 2022         Tokyo, Japan – April 1, 2022 –  KLab Inc., a leader in online mobile games, announced that the following titles will feature limited-time special campaigns in celebration of April Fool's Day. The global versions of Captain Tsubasa: Dream Team, Bleach: Brave Souls, and Utano☆Princesama Shining Live will feature in-game campaigns today only, Friday, April 1.  Users can receive amazing rewards based on the different campaigns in each title so don't miss out on this great chance to start playing!  Games Featuring April Fool's Day Campaigns Captain Tsubasa: Dream Team Bleach: Brave Souls Utano☆Princesama Shining Live  Captain Tsubasa: Dream Team  A special one-day event based off of the Captain Tsubasa comic World Youth Edition will be held in-game including an original scenario. The protagonists of the story will be Munemasa Katagiri, Minato Gamo, and Tatsuo Mikami. Users can get the new SSR Players for clearing the event scenario. There will also be a special Get UR Players as a Present! April Fools' 10-Player Transfer so be sure to check it out!  Event Period: From Friday, April 1 at 0:00 to Friday, April 1 at 23:59 JST (UTC+9)  Download here! News Sword Art Online Anime's Recap Promo Video Commemorates 10th Anniversary   posted on 2022-04-02 00:30 UTC-8 by Alex Mateo         Video features footage, music from TV series, films    Aniplex began streaming a promotional video to commemorate the 10th anniversary of the Sword Art Online anime. The 16-minute video includes footage and music from the Sword Art Online, Sword Art Online II, Sword Art Online: Alicization,  Sword Art Online the Movie: Ordinal Scale, and Sword Art Online the Movie -Progressive- Aria of a Starless Night anime.      The franchise will host a 10th anniversary event on November 6 in Tokyo.    The original Sword Art Online anime premiered in July 2012. Sword Art Online II debuted in July 2014.    Sword Art Online: Alicization premiered in Japan in October 2018, and streamed on Crunchyroll, Hulu, and FunimationNow.  Sword Art Online: Alicization - War of Underworld Part 2, the anime's "Final Season," premiered in July 2020, and it ended in September 2020.    Sword Art Online the Movie -Progressive- Aria of a Starless Night, the first anime film in the Sword Art Online the Movie -Progressive- anime film series, opened in Japan in October 2021, and topped the box office in its first weekend. Sword Art Online the Movie -Progressive- Kuraki Yūyami no Scherzo (Scherzo of a Dark Dusk), the second film, will open in Japan this fall. News Sword Art Online Anime's Recap Promo Video Commemorates 10th Anniversary   posted on 2022-04-02 00:30 UTC-8 by Alex Mateo         Video features footage, music from TV series, films    Aniplex began streaming a promotional video to commemorate the 10th anniversary of the Sword Art Online anime. The 16-minute video includes footage and music from the Sword Art Online, Sword Art Online II, Sword Art Online: Alicization,  Sword Art Online the Movie: Ordinal Scale, and Sword Art Online the Movie -Progressive- Aria of a Starless Night anime.      The franchise will host a 10th anniversary event on November 6 in Tokyo.    The original Sword Art Online anime premiered in July 2012. Sword Art Online II debuted in July 2014.    Sword Art Online: Alicization premiered in Japan in October 2018, and streamed on Crunchyroll, Hulu, and FunimationNow.  Sword Art Online: Alicization - War of Underworld Part 2, the anime's "Final Season," premiered in July 2020, and it ended in September 2020.    Sword Art Online the Movie -Progressive- Aria of a Starless Night, the first anime film in the Sword Art Online the Movie -Progressive- anime film series, opened in Japan in October 2021, and topped the box office in its first weekend. Sword Art Online the Movie -Progressive- Kuraki Yūyami no Scherzo (Scherzo of a Dark Dusk), the second film, will open in Japan this fall. The 16-minute video includes footage and music from the Sword Art Online, Sword Art Online II, Sword Art Online: Alicization,  Sword Art Online the Movie: Ordinal Scale, and Sword Art Online the Movie -Progressive- Aria of a Starless Night anime.      The franchise will host a 10th anniversary event on November 6 in Tokyo.    The original Sword Art Online anime premiered in July 2012. Sword Art Online II debuted in July 2014.    Sword Art Online: Alicization premiered in Japan in October 2018, and streamed on Crunchyroll, Hulu, and FunimationNow.  Sword Art Online: Alicization - War of Underworld Part 2, the anime's "Final Season," premiered in July 2020, and it ended in September 2020.    Sword Art Online the Movie -Progressive- Aria of a Starless Night, the first anime film in the Sword Art Online the Movie -Progressive- anime film series, opened in Japan in October 2021, and topped the box office in its first weekend. Sword Art Online the Movie -Progressive- Kuraki Yūyami no Scherzo (Scherzo of a Dark Dusk), the second film, will open in Japan this fall.    Sources: Aniplex's YouTube channel, Comic Natalie        discuss this in the forum (2 posts) |        bookmark/share with:                News homepage / archives           RightStuf - Anime, Manga and More

Forum - View topicNEWS: Viz Media to Publish Mieri Hiranishi's The Girl That Can't Get a Girlfriend Manga             Note: this is the discussion thread for this article     Anime News Network Forum Index -> Site-related -> Talkback    View previous topic :: View next topic     Author Message        TsukasaElkKite    Joined: 22 Nov 2005 		    Posts: 3579       Posted: Sat Apr 02, 2022 6:15 am            This is great. More yuri manga!      Back to top                    BluePikmin11    Joined: 24 Nov 2016 		    Posts: 21       Posted: Sat Apr 02, 2022 8:04 am            This has me confused, cause I thought VIZ were looking for manga-inspired creators in the West. Makes me think they're shifting focus. Like they haven't found anyone in the West worthy of publishing, so they resorted to Japanese mangaka.   Still, I'm pretty happy to see their work get published.      Back to top                  MFrontier    Joined: 13 Apr 2014 		    Posts: 3769       Posted: Sat Apr 02, 2022 9:50 am            Looks like a fun series. I'm happy for the author.      Back to top                  Ming Yi    Joined: 20 Dec 2005 		    Posts: 142       Posted: Sat Apr 02, 2022 1:27 pm              BluePikmin11 wrote:    This has me confused, cause I thought VIZ were looking for manga-inspired creators in the West. Makes me think they're shifting focus. Like they haven't found anyone in the West worthy of publishing, so they resorted to Japanese mangaka.   Still, I'm pretty happy to see their work get published.            That's not true? They decided to publish Devil's Candy a while back: https://www.viz.com/devil-s-candy      Back to top                  Blanchimont    Joined: 25 Feb 2012 		    Posts: 2790 		    Location: Finland 		        Posted: Sat Apr 02, 2022 1:49 pm              Ming Yi wrote:    That's not true? They decided to publish Devil's Candy a while back: https://www.viz.com/devil-s-candy      While its good there's more Western entries, I can't help but be reminded of the whole Tokyopop rights mess with their OEL lineup whenever it comes up in discussion, the authors couldn't even continue their own stories or use their own characters after TP collapsed.   In general, copyright/rights are at least shared with the author when it comes to Japanese mangaka, and they in general have a lot to say about the use of their works. How is Viz handling that aspect? Title: NEWS: Viz Media to Publish Mieri Hiranishi's The Girl That Can't Get a Girlfriend Manga - Forum - Anime News Network:SEA
Data: ข่าวสารและบทความของ Anime News Network ในรูปแบบภาษาไทย สามารถติดตามอ่านได้แล้วที่ DEXclub         กรุณาเข้าไปเยี่ยมชมได้ที่ news.dexclub.com เพื่อติดตามอ่านข่าวสารล่าสุดในรูปแบบภาษาไทย          Anime News Network's news and articles are available in Thai from DEXclub.         Visit news.dexclub.com for all the latest news in Thai.              Forum - View topicNEWS: Viz Media to Publish Mieri Hiranishi's The Girl That Can't Get a Girlfriend Manga             Note: this is the discussion thread for this article     Anime News Network Forum Index -> Site-related -> Talkback    View previous topic :: View next topic     Author Message        TsukasaElkKite    Joined: 22 Nov 2005 		    Posts: 3579       Posted: Sat Apr 02, 2022 6:15 am            This is great. More yuri manga!      Back to top                    BluePikmin11    Joined: 24 Nov 2016 		    Posts: 21       Posted: Sat Apr 02, 2022 8:04 am            This has me confused, cause I thought VIZ were looking for manga-inspired creators in the West. Makes me think they're shifting focus. Like they haven't found anyone in the West worthy of publishing, so they resorted to Japanese mangaka.   Still, I'm pretty happy to see their work get published.      Back to top                  MFrontier    Joined: 13 Apr 2014 		    Posts: 3769       Posted: Sat Apr 02, 2022 9:50 am            Looks like a fun series. I'm happy for the author.      Back to top                  Ming Yi    Joined: 20 Dec 2005 		    Posts: 142       Posted: Sat Apr 02, 2022 1:27 pm              BluePikmin11 wrote:    This has me confused, cause I thought VIZ were looking for manga-inspired creators in the West. Makes me think they're shifting focus. Like they haven't found anyone in the West worthy of publishing, so they resorted to Japanese mangaka.   Still, I'm pretty happy to see their work get published.            That's not true? They decided to publish Devil's Candy a while back: https://www.viz.com/devil-s-candy      Back to top                  Blanchimont    Joined: 25 Feb 2012 		    Posts: 2790 		    Location: Finland 		        Posted: Sat Apr 02, 2022 1:49 pm              Ming Yi wrote:    That's not true? They decided to publish Devil's Candy a while back: https://www.viz.com/devil-s-candy      While its good there's more Western entries, I can't help but be reminded of the whole Tokyopop rights mess with their OEL lineup whenever it comes up in discussion, the authors couldn't even continue their own stories or use their own characters after TP collapsed.   In general, copyright/rights are at least shared with the author when it comes to Japanese mangaka, and they in general have a lot to say about the use of their works. How is Viz handling that aspect? News Kounodori: Dr. Stork Manga Returns for New COVID-19 Arc in April (Updated)   posted on 2022-04-02 12:53 UTC-8 by Crystalyn Hodgkins         Author also launches new manga about Sakmoto Ryōma in April    Kodansha announced on Saturday that Yū Suzunoki's Kounodori: Dr. Stork (Kōnodori) manga is returning for a new arc that will focus on the new coronavirus disease (COVID-19).    The new arc, titled Kōnodori: Shingata Coronovirus-hen, will launch in Kodansha's Morning magazine on April 28. The manga will again center on Sakura Kōnotori, and will detail the struggles of being an OB/GYN involved in childbirth during the COVID-19 pandemic.    Suzunoki launched the main manga in Kodansha's Morning magazine in August 2012, and the series ended in May 2020. Kodansha published the 32nd and final volume in October 2020.    Kodansha Comics is releasing the manga in English digitally, and it describes the story:   Childbirth isn't an illness, so under normal circumstances, insurance won't cover it. Delivery staff doesn't cure disease or treat injuries, so there's no need for a doctor...unless, of course, circumstances aren't normal. This smash-hit drama gives a look into the lives of the men and women who work to welcome 1,000,000 new lives into the world each year in Japan.   The manga inspired a live-action television series in October 2015, and a sequel series premiered in October 2017.   Update: Suzunoki will also launch a new manga titled Ryōma ga Yuku based on Ryōtarō's historical novel starting in Bungeishunju's Weekly Bunshun magazine on April 28. The manga tells a fictional story about the historical figure Sakamoto Ryōma. News Kounodori: Dr. Stork Manga Returns for New COVID-19 Arc in April (Updated)   posted on 2022-04-02 12:53 UTC-8 by Crystalyn Hodgkins         Author also launches new manga about Sakmoto Ryōma in April    Kodansha announced on Saturday that Yū Suzunoki's Kounodori: Dr. Stork (Kōnodori) manga is returning for a new arc that will focus on the new coronavirus disease (COVID-19).    The new arc, titled Kōnodori: Shingata Coronovirus-hen, will launch in Kodansha's Morning magazine on April 28. The manga will again center on Sakura Kōnotori, and will detail the struggles of being an OB/GYN involved in childbirth during the COVID-19 pandemic.    Suzunoki launched the main manga in Kodansha's Morning magazine in August 2012, and the series ended in May 2020. Kodansha published the 32nd and final volume in October 2020.    Kodansha Comics is releasing the manga in English digitally, and it describes the story:   Childbirth isn't an illness, so under normal circumstances, insurance won't cover it. Delivery staff doesn't cure disease or treat injuries, so there's no need for a doctor...unless, of course, circumstances aren't normal. This smash-hit drama gives a look into the lives of the men and women who work to welcome 1,000,000 new lives into the world each year in Japan.   The manga inspired a live-action television series in October 2015, and a sequel series premiered in October 2017.   Update: Suzunoki will also launch a new manga titled Ryōma ga Yuku based on Ryōtarō's historical novel starting in Bungeishunju's Weekly Bunshun magazine on April 28. The manga tells a fictional story about the historical figure Sakamoto Ryōma.
